A bit late (a few years late !) but this is quite simple.

If the Universe has n spatial dimensions (in our Universe, there are 3), we can assume that gravity would be proportionnal to (1/R)^(n-1). A simple way to imagine this is simple : the sun sends the "gravitation" into space, and after a time t this "gravitation" reaches the surface of a hypersphere, with the sun as center. The surface of the hypersphere is a function of (1/R)^(n-1).

With this assumption, you can try to find orbits, and you can always find a circular one at any given distance. But they are only stable if n=3. And if circular orbits are not stable, every orbit cannot be stable (at any point of the orbit, if the speed isn't precisely the speed of the circular orbit, the planet will either fall into the sun or fly away, by unstability).

Well that isn't actually it. Surface area means nothing, mass is what causes gravity. It's actually because every time you increase the volume of something by one exponential power, or one dimension if you will, the mass in that volume increases by a larger amount than something smaller. Here is an example.
5                    10
5^2=25            10^2=100
5^3=125          10^3=1000
As you can see, the ten increases much faster than the five. The five is the Earth, and the ten is the Sun.

As I understand it, the way gravity changes over distance is similar to light intensity. Consider an object which emits a constant amount L of light, and stand a distance r from it. If the object is in 2d, the amount L is spread over 2*pi*r of surface at distance r, so intensity at any point is proportional to L/r. In 3d, intensity is proportional to L/(r^2). And in 4d, intensity is proportional to L/(r^3). So in 4d, moving closer to the object has a more dramatic effect on gravity than in 3d.

Google images for "inverse square law." This is how forces work in 3D. At double a given distance, the force actually drops to a quarter as strong because it is acting on 4 times more area. In 2D, at double distance, the area (or really length) is only twice as much which makes the force drop in strength by only a half. In 4D, the area (or really surface volume) is eight times as much, making the force eight times smaller. This difference in gravity's "steepness" is what he was talking about.

So in short, the ball going up and being reversed, you wouldn't be able to tell which was which (it looks realistic in both directions and you get realistic answers).  With a drop of dye in water however, you CAN tell if a video is being played in reverse. (it looks unrealistic and if you did calculations you'd find it violating 2nd law of thermodynamics) NOTE: This only applies to macroscopic world.  Quantum Mechanics does not have a direction of time.

To elaborate on the time-symmetric nature of say a Newtonian physics question... Imagine you saw a ball throw up into the air in a recording... now say you saw that same clip, only reversed.  BOTH would give the same answers AND both would be naturally possible.  (One instance the ball is thrown up one instance the ball is falling down).  Entropy however would not look realistic and you wouldn't get the same answers as observed if you were to do calculations. (ie. dye spreading in water)

Certainly, you can show that a produced pair of photons can have their polarizations somehow 'transfer information' faster than light (if taking into account the distance between them). But that is assuming that one particle sends or teleports information to the other rather than it being an inherent nature of the particle itself.

It is just standard convention that we consider the first 3 perceivable spatial dimensions as the first 3. And since time is also perceivable, but wasn't always considered a 'dimension' it is considered the 4th. Other dimensions, which aren't proven to exist (but certainly are postulated and allowed by currently accepted theories), are considered just the 'other' dimensions. This follows because we have no real understanding of their nature or whether they exit or not.

It is important to note that the number 11 arises form general relativity. Assuming GR, we can have up to 11. While there has yet to be any reasonable evidence against Einsteins beautiful theory, we cannot say without a doubt that it will not one day be disproven.

It may be hard to imagine more dimensions but we can work with lower dimensions, which can be realized in the lab. With fewer dimensions, e.g. 2D space, the mathematical expressional for gravity force is different (making it weaker), but a mathematical relation called the Gauss's law holds for both 3D and 2D. If we assume that the Gauss's law holds for any number of dimensions, and use it to derive expression for gravity, we will find that the gravity is "stronger" with more spatial dimensions.
But Reality is 4D. It is how we experience everything. How might this world progress without the fourth dimension?

The exponent on the radius term in Newton's law of gravity, is what would increase.  It is equal to the number of dimensions of the universe minus 1.

Think of how gravity "spreads out" over spherical area, the way we understand it now.  In a 2-d universe, flatland, it would "spread out" over a linear perimeter instead, and it would just be proportional to 1/r instead of 1/r^2.

We could have stable orbits in 4 dimensions, but that requires nested dimensions, eg. we live in a 4D universe which is within a higher dimension. Depending on how we are positioned in the higher dimension, the effects of gravity could be lessened. For example, a marble on a slanted table (2D) will roll off slower than if the table was steeper. That is why physicists think we could be nested in a higher dimension, because gravity is weaker than some other forces.

Heard of medicine-resistant Staphylococcus aureus? It occurs a lot in hospitals, where surfaces are constantly being disinfected. The sanitizers kill 99% of the bacteria; the ones that are most resistant survive and then breed, resulting in a population derived from only the strongest. Then the surface is re-santized, killing the weakest 99%, and the strongest 1% breed. Over generations, the sanitizer becomes less effective as the weakest organisms are weeded out. Evolution. I'm just showing point that the probability of an intelligent being creating this exact world wouldn't be any different from the likelihood of a perfect explosion. There are many more forces in the universe besides centripetal, gravity, and friction.
